instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the prediction performance in the related study to improve the prediction of key soil properties using simple ratio indices (SRI) and normalized difference indices (NDI), and how well did the SRI and NDI transformations perform compared to the untransformed data?
Output:

instruction: What machine learning techniques were employed in the related study to improve the prediction of key soil properties using simple ratio indices (SRI) and normalized difference indices (NDI) calculated from visible and near-infrared (Vis-NIR) spectra?
Output: The machine learning techniques employed in the related study to improve the prediction of key soil properties using simple ratio indices (SRI) and normalized difference indices (NDI) calculated from visible and near-infrared (Vis-NIR) spectra include partial least squares regression (PLSR), ridge regression, principal component regression (PCR), and two stacked algorithms.

instruction: Can the application of simple ratio indices (SRI) and normalized difference indices (NDI) calculated from visible and near-infrared (Vis-NIR) spectra be considered as a superior method for improving the prediction of key soil properties compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, the application of simple ratio indices (SRI) and normalized difference indices (NDI) calculated from visible and near-infrared (Vis-NIR) spectra can be considered as a superior method for improving the prediction of key soil properties compared to traditional methods. According to the study mentioned in the text, the SRI and NDI transformations significantly improved the performance of all the models compared to the untransformed data. The SRI was found to be superior to NDI in terms of prediction performance. The stacked model PCR-poly applied on the SRI data yielded the best prediction performances for all the soil properties. The findings of the study suggest that using SRI and NDI transformations on Vis-NIR data, along with employing stacked models for calibration, can yield similar prediction performances for soil properties compared to deep learning-based methods, while being computationally less demanding.
